title: MARKET REPORT: GVC cashes as gamblers change their betting habits
text:
A rise in online and over-the-counter betting has left the Ladbrokes Coral owner GVC quids in.

The FTSE 250 gambling firm raised its outlook for the second time this year, as it revealed strong results for the third quarter of 2019.

Net gaming revenue was up 12 per cent in its online division compared to last year, as both gaming and sports betting pulled in more money.

This was especially noteworthy since the same period in 2018 contained part of the football World Cup.

Ladbrokes Coral owner GVC raised its outlook for the second time this year, as it revealed strong results for the third quarter of 2019

And its High Street shops fared better than feared following the crackdown on betting machines, which were dubbed the crack cocaine of the gambling industry.

The industry has suffered since the Government cut the maximum stakes which could be wagered on fixed-odds betting terminals this year from £100 to £2.

Store revenues fell 18 per cent as it felt the pain but this was not as bad as expected as gamblers placed bets over the counter rather than on the machines.

GVC, which plans to close up to 900 of its 3,200 stores over the next two years, now thinks it will make full-year profits of between £670million and £680million, up from £650m to £670million. Shares climbed 5.2 per cent, or 38.6p, to 788.6p.

Stock Watch - Pressure Technologies Engineering group Pressure Technologies has won a contract worth more than £3million from EDF Energy to work on nuclear power plants. It will supply nitrogen storage at plants at Heysham, Torness and Hartlepool. Its cylinders, made by its Sheffield subsidiary Chesterfield Special Cylinders (CSC), will be supplied to EDF by mid-2020. Boss Chris Walters said: ‘This represents the largest order in CSC’s history outside the defence sector.’ Shares rose 9.2 per cent, or 9p, to 106.5p.

Mining titan BHP was proving less of a hit with its shareholders, however. Major investors Standard Life Aberdeen is pushing it to drop its membership of controversial lobbying groups at its annual meeting next week.

BHP is currently a member of several powerful groups which lobby for the fossil fuels industry, and have been blamed for obstructing the progress of measures designed to minimise harm to the environment.

Investors vote next week on whether BHP should quit these organisations. The company has told all investors to vote against the resolution, arguing that the lobbying bodies still have a role to play in shaping the future of the industry.

Standard Life Aberdeen owns around 5 per cent of BHP’s shares, which slipped 0.4 per cent, or 7.4p, to 1664p.

The London Stock Exchange was edging back up, after Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing dropped its bid for the group on Tuesday. Shares climbed 3.3 per cent, or 228p, to 7248p.

And Hargreaves Lansdown nudged up ahead of its shareholder meeting today after broker Liberum started its coverage on the investment platform with a ‘buy’ rating.

Hargreaves’ shares, battered over the summer as it suffered from the fallout of its relationship with troubled stockpicker Neil Woodford, rose 2.5 per cent, or 45p, to 1816.5p.

Quilter was the other investment platform which won a ‘buy’ rating from Liberum, and was up 1 per cent, or 1.2p, to 127.45p.

Integrafin (up 0.3 per cent, or 1p, to 356.5p) and Nucleus (flat at 145p) were slapped with a ‘hold’ label by the broker, while Liberum recommended investors sell AJ Bell.

Shares in the platform, which listed just last year, have already more than doubled, but Liberum said the stock’s value is now ‘hard to justify’. Shares were down 2.7 per cent, or 10p, to 363p.

Hollywood Bowl talent director Melanie Dickinson has cashed in some stock after the company’s strike on Tuesday, when it raised profit forecasts.

Dickinson, who actually heads the human resources department, sold 200,000 shares at 225p, pocketing a healthy £450,000. The stock climbed 1.3 per cent, or 3p, to 227p.

Fund manager Liontrust had some satisfying numbers for shareholders as it saw £642million of inflows into its funds in the third quarter. Shares edged up by 0.3 per cent, or 2p, to 750p.
